stories.title: Mercedes-Benz Power-Closing Doors Sever a Man's Thumb

stories.text: I have been all in on the Google product suite for a very long time.  From Gmail to Pixel to everything in between.  I haven't had any expectations of privacy from the beginning.  While I may not have liked all of Googles methods per se, I have accepted that superior functionality came at a price.  That lack of privacy was the cost of doing business so that isn't the issue that is pushing me to part ways.  What has pushed me over the edge is the discovery and realization of how "curated" my news and searches have become.  After comparing my search results for like terms and news with other search engines, and searches when I am logged in to Google and when I am not, I have come to the conclusion that for whatever reason, Google is no longer the best tool for me to search the internet for answers.  Email, search, browser and news aggregation are the main Google services I utilize.  I would love to hear suggestions regarding the best alternatives for Google services.  Thanks.
stories.title: Ask HN: Best Google Alternatives?

stories.text:
I'm not an k8s expert by any means but one of the philosophies (if I understand correctly) of that tool is that you declare your desired final state and then let k8s figure out how to get it there.

Is there a similar type of tool for db migrations? I've used a variety of migration tools like the one in Rails but I'm wondering if there is a similar one that uses the declarative idea.
stories.title: Ask HN: Is there a db migration tool with a similar philosophy as K8s
